title: Got Gas? You’re Not Alone

content: Burping, belching, farting, tooting – call it what you want, but everyone does it. That’s because we all have trapped gas in our intestinal tract. Most people pass gas between 13 and 21 times every day either through the mouth or the rectum. Lifestyle habits, particularly diet, influence how much you burp or fart, and excessive gas may signal certain medical conditions.

Some common medications, such as statins to control cholesterol, omeprazole for gastric reflux disease, antidepressants, and antihistamines, can result in gas. But for the most part, intestinal gas comes from two sources: swallowed air, and the breakdown of undigested food in your large intestine.

The air you swallow, usually while eating and drinking, can be belched back or it can travel all the way to the large intestine and cause flatulence, commonly called farting. Gulping your food, chewing gum, sucking on hard candies, drinking carbonated beverages, and smoking cause you to swallow air and may lead to excessive burping or farting, or both.

content: Rectal gas is generally a combination of swallowed air and gas produced by the action of bacteria in the colon on undigested carbohydrates. Food can move from the small intestine to the large intestine where bacteria break it down and produce hydrogen, carbon dioxide, and methane, which leave your rectum as gas.
Some people don’t fully digest certain carbohydrates found in food. Here are some common examples of foods that can cause excess gas:
bullets: Figs, dates, prunes, pears, onions, artichokes, asparagus, pears, grapes, and other foods contain fructose, a natural carbohydrate. Fructose may also be added to beverages and sweets.
Cabbage, Brussels sprouts, broccoli, cauliflower, and beans have complex carbohydrates that can be hard to digest.
Packaged, sweet foods such as sugar-free gum and candy, and certain medications may contain sugar alcohols, such as sorbitol and xylitol, that are difficult to completely break down.
Lactose, found naturally in milk, is hard to digest for people who lack lactase. Lactase is found in the small intestine, and it digests lactose before it reaches the large intestine.

Fiber, found in fruit, vegetables, beans, and other plant foods, is a complex carbohydrate that can cause gas when consumed in large amounts.  Fiber is also added to foods such as cereal bars in the form of inulin or chicory root. Check ingredient labels for added fiber.

sections.heading: Excessive Gas Can Signal Health Problems
content: Gassiness may be a problem if it happens often, bothers you, or affects your daily life. It may also be a sign that something else is going on medically. Occasional burping is reasonable, but excessive belching may mean an overgrowth of bacteria in the small intestine or gastric reflux disease .

Sometimes flatulence happens more often than expected, and this can be embarrassing. Extreme flatulence can even interfere with a person's ability to work and socialize comfortably or work with other people. Excessive flatulence could also be a sign of irritable bowel syndrome, intestinal infection, gluten intolerance, celiac disease, and other conditions.
How to Cut Down on Gas

You can help minimize burping and flatulence by eating and drinking slowly, thoroughly chewing food before swallowing, avoiding carbonated drinks, gum, and candies, and not smoking. If you can’t figure out what’s causing excessive gas, keep a diary for a few days and consider all the medications and supplements you take. Write down everything you eat and when you feel most gassy to get a better idea of how food affects you.

content: If you find out that beans or dairy products bother you, try over-the-counter products that contain enzymes that break up the carbohydrates in beans or dairy foods. Lactose-free dairy foods are useful for those with lactose intolerance. Or work with a registered dietitian nutritionist (RDN) who can help you safely eliminate certain foods to see if they are the cause of your problem.
You may also want to talk to your doctor if you’ve tried eliminating foods and habits that you thought were causing gas, but you’re not getting results.
